head.title: Parade of History and Decorative Art

hedline.hl1: Parade of History and Decorative Art

block.p: Benefit Bazaar Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center; (212) 727-3100.

Tonight at 6, a benefit bazaar featuring clothing, furniture, textiles, artwork and decorative objects by Dale Chihuly, Todd Oldham, Julie Taymor, Dakota Jackson and Moss will be for sale in a benefit for Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS. Performances by Cirque du Soleil will take place at 8 and 10 p.m. Tickets start at $250.
Simplifying Design Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street; (212) 753-1722.
Benefit Bazaar Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center; (212) 727-3100.

Tonight at 6, a benefit bazaar featuring clothing, furniture, textiles, artwork and decorative objects by Dale Chihuly, Todd Oldham, Julie Taymor, Dakota Jackson and Moss will be for sale in a benefit for Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS. Performances by Cirque du Soleil will take place at 8 and 10 p.m. Tickets start at $250.
Simplifying Design Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street; (212) 753-1722.

The first of three design lectures offered by the Architectural League of New York will take place tonight at 6:30, with a discussion about using fewer materials to make simpler objects that are still considered beautiful.

The second program, on Tuesday at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, will be about ecologically friendly industrial design. The third program, next Thursday, will examine graphic design and information overload in print media on the Internet, at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue.
The fee for each program is $7.
Glass Art Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue; (718) 638-5000.

An exhibition of glass works by 13 artists working in Brooklyn starts Saturday and runs through Sept. 3. The works, inspired by items in the museum's collection, include glass versions of a Persian carpet and a American Indian basket; a vase; a photo-realistic mural; a whale mask; and a three-dimensional version of a still life painting.

Open Wednesday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (except the first Saturday of every month, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.). Admission is $4; students and people 62 and older, $2; children younger than 12, no charge.
A Legacy in Print New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway (near Houston Street); (212) 219-1222.

An exhibition of more than 200 examples of the work of Tibor Kalman, the graphic designer, starts Saturday and runs through Aug. 20. Mr. Kalman, who died last May, worked on the retrospective exhibition of graphic, film and product designs.

His clients included the Limited stores, the Talking Heads and the 42nd Street Redevelopment Corporation. Open Wednesday and Sunday, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursday through Saturday, noon to 8 p.m. Admission is $6; those 65 and older, $3; no charge, members and those younger than 18.
Jamaica, Up Close King Manor Museum, Jamaica Avenue at 153d Street, Jamaica, Queens; (718) 206-0545.
The museum will offer an illustrated lecture exploring the history of Jamaica since the railroad arrived in 1836, on Saturday at 1 p.m.
On May 20 at 1 p.m., Barry Lewis, an architectural historian, will give a walking tour of the neighborhood. Reservations are suggested. Fee, each event, $5; those younger than 16, $2.
Art Fair Benefit Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (66th Street); (212) 744-5022, ext. 1282.

An opening night preview of the International Fine Art Fair, to benefit Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, a social services organization, will take place next Thursday, starting at 5:30 p.m. The event will include a cocktail reception and dinner, with table settings and interior vignettes by 40 designers. Tickets for the reception only start at $250; including dinner, $1,000.
The art fair will run from May 12 through 18. Open daily, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m., except Sunday and Wednesday, till 7 p.m. Admission is $15. Show information: (212) 472-0590.
Walking the East Side Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts; (212) 535-2526.

The group will offer a walking tour focusing on the art galleries, museums and homes of art collectors on the Upper East Side, on May 13 at 11 a.m. Meet at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 70th Street. Fee, $10; members, $8.
Interiors Behind Glass Housing Works Thrift Shop, 143 West 17th Street; (212) 366-0820.

One of two windows at the shop will be the site of a project by Donald Hill Interiors, a design firm, to develop and furnish an interior space. The second window will feature a collection of objects donated by interior designers. The objects in both windows will be sold in a silent auction to benefit Housing Works, a social services organization for the homeless and people with H.I.V. and AIDS. Through May 12.
CALENDAR
